      they are fifty years old or older. 



TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWSHere is an early preview of what we 
      are planning for tonight's CBS EVENING NEWS... Good 
      afternoon, Katie's on assignment today. This is Anthony 
      Mason filling in. CBS News reported today that the patient 
      with extreme drug-resistant tuberculosis is 31-year-old Atlanta lawyer 
      Andrew Haley Speaker. In a strange twist, Speaker's new father-in-law is a 
      government scientist who has studied tuberculosis - but he says there's no 
      connection to his son-in-law's infection. Kelly Cobiella will have 
      the very latest on this evolving story and will also tell us how the 
      public is reacting. Also, the ease in which the patient crossed the 
      country's border has exposed cracks in the national security system. 
      Nancy Cordes will look at what this case can illustrate about our 
      country's preparedness. In Iraq, the troop surge has reached full 
      strength. But does it have a chance of succeeding by September? David 
      Martin will talk with one Lieutenant General who is not optimistic. 
      Meanwhile, President Bush prepared to clash with other world 
      leaders at the upcoming G-8 summit by announcing his own plan for battling 
      climate change. Who's backing it and who's calling it just another smoke 
      screen? Jim Axelrod will have the answers. Hate e-mail 
      Spam? You might be seeing a little bit less of it. Robert Alan Soloway, 
      now known as one of the world's top spammers, was arrested today. Bill 
      Whitaker will tell you how this could affect your in-box. Also 
      tonight, we'll take you inside the place a sophisticated form of drug 
      dealing takes place - and it looks just like a doctor's office. They're 
      called pill mills, and are the source of a CBS News investigation, which 
      reveals the ease with which prescription drugs can be purchased - without 
      a prescription. Chief Investigative Correspondent Armen Keteyian 
      will report. Finally, Byron Pitts will give you a look at 
      the library dedicated today to Rev. Billy Graham. I hope 
      you'll join us for this and more, Anthony Mason

TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANJoin Dave tonight on The Late 
      Show with talk show host Regis Philbin... 
      Plus, musical guest Darlene Love! 



FRIDAY
MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOWHarry 
      Smith, Hannah Storm, and Russ Mitchell anchor 
      THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Julie Chen anchors from 
      Los Angeles. Bryan Norcross of our Miami affiliate, WFOR, will 
      bring us the weather. Dave Price is off. Along with the 
      top news of the day, we will also have the following stories:
AMERICAN IDOL WINNER JORDIN SPARKS: She is only 17 years 
      old, but already the future looks very bright for Jordin Sparks. This 
      powerhouse singer impressed millions of people with her big voice and 
      bubbly personality making her the youngest contestant to take the coveted 
      idol crown. Sparks, daughter of a former New York Giants cornerback, has 
      been readying herself for Idol fame since she was 12. She will join 
      us Friday morning with her take on her instant success. Plus, don't miss 
      her exciting performance on our plaza! STUDY HALL - DANCE 
      TEACHER: Everyone has probably had a teacher that they remember as 
      being special. In our Study Hall, Early Show's
Susan McGinnis will introduce us to Anna Lindsey of Birmingham, AL 
      who has been teaching high-schoolers how to dance for more than three 
      decades. At age 76, Lindsey could retire but she is determined to continue 
      a program that gives kids an outlet to express themselves. We'll meet this 
      inspiring lady Friday. BIRDWATCHING 101: It's been referred 
      to as the number one spectator sport. And if you're thinking Nascar, you 
      would be wrong. Believe it or not, it's bird watching! In fact, one out of 
      every five of us is a bird watcher, and it's a hobby that continues to 
      grow in popularity. Andy Thompson knows first hand. His family has been 
      publishing Bird Watcher's Digest for almost thirty years. He will 
      join us with the basics of backyard bird watching. POTTERY BARN 
      WEDDING REGISTRY: Wedding registries can be very helpful in creating 
      an ideal foundation for a couple's new home. But with more choices than 
      ever, the process often becomes a daunting task. To help make it easier, 
      design expert Susanna Salk will join us at the Pottery Barn in New 
      York with advice on what exactly you need to register for. If you 
      would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, 
      please click on the following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com 


 
SATURDAY ON 
      48 HOURS
48 Hours Mystery is preempted on Saturday 
      night. We'll be back next Tuesday with a show called, Love and 
      Lies. Murder exposes the secret lives of a suburban couple. 
      Peter Van Sant reports, Tuesday, June 5, 10 p.m. ET/PT. 
      If you would like more information on any of these stories or the 
      broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail us at: 48hours@cbsnews.com 



SUNDAY ON 60 MINUTES
JACK KEVORKIAN: Mike Wallace talks to 
      Dr. Jack Kevorkian in his first post-prison interview. The assisted 
      suicide activist went to prison as a result of his first interview with 
      Wallace, in which he showed himself on videotape injecting lethal 
      chemicals into a patient suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease. 
      VANESSA REDGRAVE: Up for a Tony Award for her solo role in 
      a play based on the Joan Didion best-selling book The Year of Magical 
      Thinking, Vanessa Redgrave talks to Mike Wallace for the first 
      time since 1979, when she appeared on 60 Minutes at the peak of her political activism. PRESIDENT 
      AHMADINEJAD: 60 Minutes re-broadcasts parts 
      of Mike Wallace's exclusive and rare interview with the president 
      of Iran.
